__data__.text:
The main cattle market in London was historically located at Smithfield, but due to overcrowding, public health issues, and traffic congestion, it was moved to a new site in Islington called the Metropolitan Cattle Market in 1855. This market experienced significant growth due to a larger population and increased money wages, as well as the importation of livestock from various parts of Great Britain, Ireland, and the Continent, following the repeal of the Corn Laws in 1842-6.

Despite warnings from veterinary scientist John Gamgee about the dangers of importing diseases, the trade continued, leading to the introduction of rinderpest, a highly contagious and deadly disease for immunologically naïve cattle. The 1865 cattle plague epidemic resulted in the establishment of a second, quarantine market, known as the Foreign Cattle Market, to prevent the spread of diseases like rinderpest, pleuro-pneumonia, and foot-and-mouth disease.

The Foreign Cattle Market was built on the Thames' south bank, near the Deptford royal dockyard, which was chosen for its large size and river frontage. The market was designed to accommodate up to three cattle boats at once, with three timber piers and platforms at two levels to facilitate cattle discharge at any tide. The market aimed to serve as a quarantine facility, ensuring that animals were slaughtered within 10 days of arrival and preventing the spread of diseases to the general population.

The Metropolitan Cattle Market was moved to a new site in Islington, called the Foreign Cattle Market, in 1855 due to various issues at the Smithfield location. The new market was built on the Thames' south bank, near the Deptford royal dockyard, which was chosen for its large size and river frontage. The dockyard, which had a rich history including visits from Elizabeth I and Peter the Great, was converted into a cattle market with a capacity for 5,000 cattle and 14,000 sheep. The market was designed to serve as a quarantine facility, ensuring that animals were slaughtered within 10 days of arrival to prevent the spread of diseases. The market was opened in 1872 and by 1880, most cattle and sheep imported into the UK were slaughtered at Deptford. The market was surrounded by a high boundary wall and included services such as bank branches, a postal telegraph office, and a pub. Trading was done through private bargain and the buyers, who were mostly wholesale butchers, had access to slaughterhouse space on the premises. The market was not an auction market and weights were guesstimated by professionals. The volume of trade fluctuated, but by 1907, 78% of London's live cattle trade went to Deptford.

The Metropolitan Cattle Market moved to a new location in Islington, called the Foreign Cattle Market, in 1855. This market, built on the Thames' south bank, had a capacity for 5,000 cattle and 14,000 sheep and was used as a quarantine facility to prevent disease spread. By 1880, most imported cattle and sheep were slaughtered here. Slaughtermen, paid based on results, would kill and butcher animals within 10 days, with buyers taking away the meat, offal, hides, and fleeces, often reselling them at Smithfield. By 1907, 78% of London's live cattle trade went to Deptford.

The market, which saw 9.4 million animals by 1887, purchased three paddle steamers to accommodate over 1.6 million animals from cattle boats coming from the Continent. The market was clean and animals were slaughtered humanely, with veterinary surgeons examining animals upon landing. Quarantine rules aimed to minimize but couldn't eliminate the importation of contagious diseases.

The City hired George Philcox, a 28-year-old Southend station-master, as superintendent, who managed the market for 40 years. The market employed about 110 direct employees and 1,500 casual workers, including drovers and slaughtermen, who were paid per piecework with irregular hours and precarious employment.

In 1855, the Metropolitan Cattle Market relocated to the Foreign Cattle Market in Islington, which could accommodate 5,000 cattle and 14,000 sheep. George Philcox, a 28-year-old Southend station-master, was hired as superintendent and managed the market for 40 years. The market employed around 110 direct workers and 1,500 casual workers, including drovers and slaughtermen, who were paid per piecework with irregular hours and unstable employment. The market's conditions were investigated by social researcher Charles Booth, who reported that drovers and slaughtermen could earn high wages but with unpredictable employment due to changing animal disease regulations. The market's closure in 1912 after Philcox's death was met with efforts to reopen it.

Drovers were responsible for driving animals off the boats and were mostly former "ochre boys" who marked animals for butchers. Slaughtermen worked in gangs of four and earned high wages but had brutalizing work that led to heavy drinking. Women, known as "gut girls," were assigned the unpleasant job of cleaning cattle and sheep intestines for sausage skins and condoms after men went on strike for higher pay. The work was described as having a foul stench and was physically demanding.

In the late 19th century, the Metropolitan Cattle Market in Deptford, also known as the Foreign Cattle Market, became a major international meat market, supplying roughly half of London's meat. The market, which could hold 5,000 cattle and 14,000 sheep, was managed by George Philcox for 40 years. The market employed around 110 direct workers and 1,500 casual workers, including drovers, slaughtermen, and women, known as "gut girls," who cleaned cattle and sheep intestines for sausage skins and condoms. These jobs were physically demanding and had foul odors. In 1891, men went on strike for higher pay, and the work was then assigned to women. The gut girls earned good wages for the time, but the work was so unpleasant that Queen Victoria took an interest and had her daughter-in-law, the Duchess of Albany, investigate. The Duchess was horrified and complained, leading to the banning of the practice and the unemployment of the women. A charity, the Deptford Fund, was started to support them. The market's closure in 1912 was met with efforts to reopen it. The market was the center of a global network of commercial relationships that connected livestock producers from distant parts of the world with consumers in London.

The Metropolitan Cattle Market in Deptford was a major international meat market in the late 19th century, sourcing roughly half of London's meat from a network of commercial relationships that spanned Europe and later, the United States. Although most European animals came from Rotterdam and Hamburg, they were part of a larger network of railways extending into Hungary, Poland, and Galicia. The Dutch ports alone sent 150,000 cattle and 250,000 sheep to Britain, with some shipments arriving directly from the port of Kronstadt, Russia.

The European livestock trade gradually declined by the late 1880s due to disease endemic in places like Prussia, where cattle smuggling was prevalent. The United States became the main supplier, with 3,144,400 American cattle landed at Deptford by 1913. American livestock exports to England were driven by a surplus that could not be absorbed by local demand.

The American West provided the surplus, with early Western cattle like Texas longhorns being replaced by higher-quality breeds through crossbreeding with Shorthorn and Hereford blood. This upgrading was a response to the demand for better cattle in the English export trade. By 1884, 95% of cattle exported came from the West. The transportation of a 1,200-pound steer from the western U.S. to Deptford market cost only 4d a pound, including all charges. The improvement in the quality of American cattle was mainly due to the introduction of the Hereford bull, which led to better beef and overall improvement in the industry.

The Metropolitan Cattle Market in Deptford was a significant international meat market in the late 19th century, with most of London's meat sourced from a network of commercial relationships spanning Europe and later, the United States. However, due to disease in Europe and an increasing surplus in the United States, American livestock became the main supplier by the late 1880s. High-quality breeds from the American West, particularly those crossbred with Shorthorn and Hereford blood, were in high demand for their superior beef. The transportation of a 1,200-pound steer from the western U.S. to Deptford market cost only 4d a pound, including all charges.

Similar improvements were made in the sheep trade. By 1884, 95% of cattle and sheep exported came from the West. The trade had a significant impact on the American livestock industry, leading to the growth of the Western packinghouse industry, the expansion of railway traffic, and the growth of livestock herds. Additionally, some British agriculturalists and investors began engaging in American ranching and making significant contributions to its development.

Canadian range cattle, primarily from Alberta and Assiniboia, were also a major export industry at the time. They were shipped east on the Canadian Pacific Railway and initially considered disease-free, allowing for free landing at Deptford. However, from 1892 on, they were scheduled for slaughter at Deptford due to the movement of high-quality cattle to the British market.

As the North American surplus dwindled, Deptford's main supply of animals came from Argentina. The Argentine beef industry transformed into the greatest exporter in the world due to selective breeding and the introduction of alfalfa forage. Live cattle and sheep were shipped as deck cargo from Buenos Aires to London, taking about 30 days.

As the North American supply of livestock decreased, Argentina became the primary source of animals for the Deptford market. Argentine cattle were initially of inferior quality, used locally for hides, bones, and tallow. However, the industry transformed with selective breeding and the introduction of alfalfa forage, making Argentina the world's leading beef exporter. Live cattle and sheep were shipped to London from Buenos Aires in deck cargo, but this trade declined after 1900 due to foot-and-mouth disease and the availability of chilled beef.

From Australia and New Zealand, cattle and sheep were shipped to Deptford Market, although the trade experienced significant losses during long voyages. By 1900, the Beef Trust, a cartel of large Chicago meat packers, controlled the shipping of live cattle from America to England. They allegedly manipulated the British beef market by controlling lairages at Deptford and sending meat directly to Smithfield Market, leading to cancelled market days. An inquiry in 1909 confirmed these practices but found that the Trust could not fix the price of beef due to declining American exports and increasing Argentine refrigerated beef shipments. Animal welfare was a concern during these long journeys.

In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, the Beef Trust, a cartel of large American meat packers, manipulated the British beef market by controlling lairages at Deptford and sending meat directly to Smithfield Market, leading to cancelled market days at Deptford. This was part of a larger issue of control and manipulation in the meat industry, as American beef exports declined and Argentina became a major exporter of refrigerated beef. Animal welfare was a significant concern during this time, as animals were shipped from around the world to be slaughtered at Deptford market, often experiencing stress and injury during long journeys. Early attempts to ship cattle across the Atlantic were fraught with difficulties, including poor conditions and high mortality rates, particularly in the winter months. Samuel Plimsoll, a prominent advocate for maritime safety, campaigned against the transatlantic cattle trade due to its dangers and cruelty to animals.

In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, Samuel Plimsoll advocated for the abolition of the dangerous and inhumane transatlantic cattle trade. He highlighted the instability of cattle ships during storms, the cruel treatment of animals, and the unnecessary risks taken by captains. Plimsoll also criticized the poor conditions on board, such as the buildup of animal waste and the use of cruel methods to force animals to stand. Although Plimsoll's campaign was unsuccessful in ending the trade, it did lead to some improvements in British and American regulations. The export trade was dominated by the Beef Trust, a cartel of large American meat packers, who established a liner system to ensure the timely and safe transport of livestock across the Atlantic. Despite these efforts, conditions on board the ships remained harsh, with animals often suffering from injuries and stress during the long journey. The cattle were transported to market by train, often making lengthy journeys to Chicago and then to ports on the eastern seaboard for shipment to England. The US had regulations in place to limit the amount of time animals could travel without a break, but it is unclear if these regulations were always followed.

In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, the transatlantic cattle trade, dominated by the Beef Trust, involved shipping livestock from the US and Canada to England. The journey by sea could last up to 11 days, during which animals might suffer injuries and stress. Before boarding ships, cattle were transported by train, often for lengthy periods, with inadequate rest, food, and water. Overcrowding and rough handling were common, leading to injuries and exhaustion. Samuel Plimsoll criticized this trade, arguing it was inhumane and had no commercial purpose beyond enriching unscrupulous traders. Although regulations were in place, their enforcement was inconsistent, and animals continued to suffer during transportation. Canadian cattle exports were particularly harsh, with cattle enduring long rail journeys and arriving in Britain "gaunt and shrunken."

In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, the transatlantic cattle trade, particularly from Canada, was criticized for its inhumane treatment of animals and lack of commercial purpose beyond enriching dishonest traders. Cattle endured long rail journeys, often arriving in England "gaunt and shrunken." Samuel Plimsoll argued that importing live cattle served no rational commercial purpose when beef could be more cheaply and easily imported and in better condition. An alternative, American chilled meat, was already being imported into London in 1875 and was a commercial success. However, consumers were charged a premium for Deptford-killed American beef, possibly due to fraudulent reselling as Scotch or English beef. Chilled meat was considered as good as, if not better than, Deptford-killed beef by Plimsoll, as it was equivalent to well-hung meat. However, consumers' tastes, prejudices, and snobbery might have influenced their perception of chilled beef. Richard Perren suggested that the live meat trade survived because the chilled meat trade was riskier, as consignments had to be sold promptly upon arrival, while there was less urgency with live beasts. However, once cold-storage was available at ports, chilled meat could keep for an additional 14 days, and livestock had to be slaughtered within 10 days of arrival. The live animal trade was also risky, and the chilled trade was the bigger of the two.

Plimsoll maintained that consumers should have the choice to pay more for British beef if they prefer, but he believed that the live cattle trade persisted because the chilled meat trade was riskier. Consignments of chilled meat needed to be sold quickly upon arrival, whereas live animals could be slaughtered later. However, once cold storage was available at ports, chilled meat could be stored for an additional two weeks. Although the live animal trade was also risky, the chilled trade was larger. Some butchers fraudulently sold Deptford-killed meat as English or Scottish beef, which was easier to do before compulsory marking of origin was introduced in 1933. A 2010 study found that there were incentives to misrepresent American beef as Scottish/English, but they declined over time and ceased to exist by 1911. The transatlantic cattle trade had an unexpected benefit of making bread cheaper by providing an easy way to ballast vessels with American grain. Ultimately, the market declined due to an embargo on Argentine cattle and diminishing American and Canadian supplies, leading to its closure in 1913.

Post-war, the market in Deptford, London was sold to the government and transformed into a supply base for troops in France. Some remnants of the market and former dockyard still exist as listed buildings, known as Convoys Wharf. The site had previously been significant for the transatlantic cattle trade, which provided an easy way to transport American grain for ballast. The trade eventually declined due to an embargo on Argentine cattle and decreasing American and Canadian supplies, leading to its closure in 1913. This summary is based on information from various sources, including Booth (1896), Bernier (1903), Bicknell (1903, 1904), BMJ leader (1865), Board of Agriculture (1891, 1901), Board of Agriculture and Fisheries (1906), Board of Trade (1909), Booth (1895, 1900), Brayer (1949), Brown (1873, 1879), Bryden (1891), Capie and Perren (1980), and Chadwick et al. (1891).

The texts from 1879 to 1918 discuss the transatlantic cattle trade, its regulations, and the diseases affecting livestock. The trade was significant for transporting American grain for ballast and supplying meat to Britain. However, it faced challenges such as embargoes on Argentine cattle, decreasing American and Canadian supplies, and outbreaks of diseases like pleuropneumonia. These issues led to the implementation of regulations, such as the Diseases of Animals Act in 1896 and the 28-Hour Law in 1918, to ensure animal welfare and prevent the spread of diseases during transportation. The decline of the transatlantic cattle trade eventually resulted in its closure in 1913. The information is based on reports and studies from various sources, including government documents, journals, and books.

The provided texts discuss various aspects of the meat industry, with a focus on the transatlantic cattle trade from the late 19th to the early 20th century. Topics include the regulation of livestock transportation, animal welfare, meat supply, and the impact of diseases like pleuropneumonia. Specific regulations mentioned are the Diseases of Animals Act in 1896 and the 28-Hour Law in 1918. The literature also touches on the misrepresentation of meat origins and the role of technology in slaughtering practices. The sources include government documents, journals, and books from the period.

The provided texts discuss various aspects of the meat industry, with a focus on the transatlantic cattle trade from the late 19th to the early 20th century. Some texts cover the regulation of livestock transportation, including the Diseases of Animals Act in 1896 and the 28-Hour Law in 1918. Animal welfare and meat supply are also discussed, along with the impact of diseases like pleuropneumonia. The role of technology in slaughtering practices and the misrepresentation of meat origins are touched upon as well. The sources include personal accounts, government documents, journals, and books from the period.

In particular, "Five Thousand Miles With Range-Cattle" is a personal account of the cattle trade, while "Contagious Pleuro-pneumonia" discusses the impact of the disease on the industry. "Food from the Far West, or American Agriculture" highlights the role of the American West in meat production, and "Humanitarian Reform, Slaughter Technology, and Butcher Resistance in Nineteenth-Century Britain" explores the resistance to new slaughtering practices. "Meat Production in the Argentine and its Effect upon the Industry in the United States" compares meat production in the US and Argentina, and "Municipal Terminal Markets" discusses the importance of terminal markets in the meat industry.

"On the Atlantic Cattle Trade" discusses the transportation of cattle across the Atlantic, and "The 'Echua' Shipment" covers a specific shipment of cattle. "The Practical Statutes of the Session 1869" includes relevant legislation, and "The Cow Country" provides a historical overview of the cattle industry in the US. "Influences of the British Market on Agriculture and Related Economic Development in Europe before 1860" and "The North American Beef and Cattle Trade with Great Britain, 1870-1914" discuss the impact of the British market on the meat industry.

"The Meat and Livestock Trade in Britain, 1850-70" and "Taste, Trade and Technology: the Development of the International Meat Industry Since 1840" provide historical context, and "Live Stock and Meat Traffic of Chicago" discusses the role of Chicago in the meat industry

The text discusses various aspects of the international meat industry, with a focus on the cattle trade in different regions and time periods. It covers the impact of transportation on cattle health, the development of new slaughtering practices, and the role of technology in meat production. The text also touches on the influence of market rights, tolls, and consumer demand on the meat industry. Sources include personal accounts, government documents, and academic publications from the 19th to the 20th century. Some specific topics covered include the live stock and meat traffic of Chicago, the transatlantic cattle trade, and the exportation of cattle. The impact of diseases on the meat industry is also discussed, along with the role of cattle breeds in regional geography.

The text discusses the impact of transportation on cattle health and meat production, with a focus on the cattle trade in Deptford, London. It covers the role of market rights, tolls, and consumer demand in shaping the meat industry. The development of new slaughtering practices and the influence of technology on meat production are also discussed. Sources include personal accounts, government documents, and academic publications from the 19th to the 20th century. The text also touches on the exportation of cattle and the impact of diseases on the meat industry. The live cattle trade between the United States and Great Britain, specifically in the late 19th century, is also discussed. The text includes newspaper articles and government reports that detail the establishment and operation of the Deptford Foreign Cattle Market. The text also highlights the role of purebred cattle in regional geography and the impact of the "Beef Trust" on London's meat supplies. The text also includes the funeral notice of Mr George Philcox, a prominent figure in the meat industry. The text also discusses the failure of the Foreign Cattle Market in 1913.

The summarized text covers various news articles and publications from the late 19th to the early 20th century, discussing the meat industry in London, specifically in Deptford. The articles detail the impact of market rights, tolls, consumer demand, and technology on the cattle trade. The role of purebred cattle in regional geography and the influence of the "Beef Trust" on London's meat supplies are also discussed. The articles mention the establishment and operation of the Deptford Foreign Cattle Market, its failure in 1913, and the subsequent decay of the industry. The text also highlights the impact of diseases on the meat industry and the exportation of cattle, specifically between the United States and Great Britain. The articles also include personal accounts and campaigning pamphlets related to the cattle trade. The text also touches on the funeral notice of Mr George Philcox, a prominent figure in the meat industry.
